text: I think I'd been interested in writing
since I don't know I was 12 or whatever
I've I've always kept journals certainly
steadily for the last 60 years um I
didn't know how the writing and science
and medicine could come together or if
they would ever come together but they
did seem to come together in the stories
of patients and case
histories and um I uh I had in fact
written my first book on migraine before
I encountered these patients at Beth
Abraham uh I would recommend keeping a
journal period I hadn't thought of it
particularly as a happiness producing
device I mean I think for myself um
there's always been a need to make some
sort of narrative sense and to describe
people and events and situations and
feelings and uh um and I need to keep a
journal partly as a as an act of
clarification partly also because that
it allows my imagination and fantasy
free reign but somehow H held within a
sort of framework but I I just I hugely
enjoy the act of writing and I find it
absolutely necessary um and I um whether
it's keeping a journal or any other sort
of writing I'm certainly unhappy when I
can't write so for me uh writing is a
central form of uh of uh of Happiness uh
not specifically keeping a journal but
for someone else that may be sort of I I
mean I think I think anything something
creative is needed
